title: Prototype pollution attack (deap)

profile.name: Node.js third-party modules
profile.about: This program is used to handle vulnerabilities in the Node.js ecosystem.

vulnerability_information:
As discussed in #309391, here's the separate report for each of the library. This one is the information for the deap library.

**Module:**

[deap](https://www.npmjs.com/package/deap)

**Summary:**

Utilities function in all the listed modules can be tricked into modify the prototype of "Object" when the attacker control part of the structure passed to these function. This can let an attacker add or modify existing property that will exist on all object.

**Description:** 

## Steps To Reproduce:

The simplest test case to reproduce the issue is the following code snippet. In the code snippet, "malicious_payload" would come from an endpoint which accepts JSON data. The test case also works with the "deap.extend" function, the "deap" function and the "deap.clone" function.

> var deap= require('deap');
> var malicious_payload = '{"\_\_proto\_\_":{"oops":"It works !"}}';
> 
> var a = {};
> console.log("Before : " + a.oops);
> deap.merge({}, JSON.parse(malicious_payload));
> console.log("After : " + a.oops);

This shows that an attacker can add attributes to all existing object on the server. Additional attribute can be used to change the execution code flow or cause error on every subsequent request by replacing "toString" or "valueOf".

## Impact: 

This vulnerability is garanteed to at least obtain denial of service as all the library allow the property "toString" and "valueOf" to be replaced by a "String". This breaks the express module and forces the server to either crash or return a 500 to every subsequent request.

More complex payload can be crafted to gain remote code execution (see PoC in #309391).

## Supporting Material/References:

If extra information is needed don't hesitate to ask.

## Impact

Variable. Server crash or the server becoming unable to respond to all request is garanteed, but more significant impact like remote code execution can be achieved in some cases.
vulnerability_information_html:
As discussed in #309391, here's the separate report for each of the library. This one is the information for the deap library.

Module:

deap

Summary:

Utilities function in all the listed modules can be tricked into modify the prototype of "Object" when the attacker control part of the structure passed to these function. This can let an attacker add or modify existing property that will exist on all object.

Description:

Steps To Reproduce:

The simplest test case to reproduce the issue is the following code snippet. In the code snippet, "malicious_payload" would come from an endpoint which accepts JSON data. The test case also works with the "deap.extend" function, the "deap" function and the "deap.clone" function.

var deap= require('deap');
var malicious_payload = '{"__proto__":{"oops":"It works !"}}';

var a = {};
console.log("Before : " + a.oops);
deap.merge({}, JSON.parse(malicious_payload));
console.log("After : " + a.oops);

This shows that an attacker can add attributes to all existing object on the server. Additional attribute can be used to change the execution code flow or cause error on every subsequent request by replacing "toString" or "valueOf".

Impact:

This vulnerability is garanteed to at least obtain denial of service as all the library allow the property "toString" and "valueOf" to be replaced by a "String". This breaks the express module and forces the server to either crash or return a 500 to every subsequent request.

More complex payload can be crafted to gain remote code execution (see PoC in #309391).

Supporting Material/References:

If extra information is needed don't hesitate to ask.

Impact

Variable. Server crash or the server becoming unable to respond to all request is garanteed, but more significant impact like remote code execution can be achieved in some cases.

activities.message: I was able to reproduce the issue (with a change in the variable name). Have you tried to contact the maintainer yet @holyvier ?

activities.message: I am one of the maintainers. It would be great if someone could grant me access to see #309391.

activities.message: That issue contains the list of all the package affected by this issue. It will be opened once all the package are fixed. We are still in the process of communicating with package maintainer on this.

activities.message: @prestaul did you have time to look at the issue?
activities.markdown_message: @prestaul did you have time to look at the issue?

activities.message: @vdeturckheim, I've looked at the issue and wrote some unit tests to demonstrate it. We aren't sure how we want to approach a fix yet because everything we've considered just seems ugly. Are there examples of fixes others have applied you should send us?
activities.markdown_message: @vdeturckheim, I've looked at the issue and wrote some unit tests to demonstrate it. We aren't sure how we want to approach a fix yet because everything we've considered just seems ugly. Are there examples of fixes others have applied you should send us?

activities.message:
Sorry for the delay. There's a few library that the issue is now public :

 - https://hackerone.com/reports/310443
 - https://hackerone.com/reports/310439
 - https://hackerone.com/reports/310708

I believe most of them opted to blacklist "\_\_proto__". You can also implement the merge a bit differently to avoid the issue. Something along the line of the following snippet would to do it : 

https://gist.github.com/HoLyVieR/0e6df0f7e82b7b55987add106d3a1bbc

However, it modifies slightly the behavior of the merge by creating new object with the same property instead of reusing existing one (may break thing). It also has the side-effect that "\_\_proto__" assignation will change the prototype of the object (probably not too much of an issue though). It's a bit tricky to handle and I'm not entirely sure either what's the best way to patch this.
activities.markdown_message:
Sorry for the delay. There's a few library that the issue is now public :

  • https://hackerone.com/reports/310443
  • https://hackerone.com/reports/310439
  • https://hackerone.com/reports/310708

I believe most of them opted to blacklist "__proto__". You can also implement the merge a bit differently to avoid the issue. Something along the line of the following snippet would to do it :

https://gist.github.com/HoLyVieR/0e6df0f7e82b7b55987add106d3a1bbc

However, it modifies slightly the behavior of the merge by creating new object with the same property instead of reusing existing one (may break thing). It also has the side-effect that "__proto__" assignation will change the prototype of the object (probably not too much of an issue though). It's a bit tricky to handle and I'm not entirely sure either what's the best way to patch this.

activities.message:
Thanks for the feedback. I've implemented a fix in https://github.com/selfcontained/deap/pull/4

Hoping to ship a new patch version later today.
activities.markdown_message:
Thanks for the feedback. I've implemented a fix in https://github.com/selfcontained/deap/pull/4

Hoping to ship a new patch version later today.

activities.message: Hey @prestaul did you manage to publish a new version? What is it's number?
